| Overview                = The '''Beatles''' were an English rock group from [[Liverpool]] that shaped not only music but also an entire generation. With 20 songs that hit #1 on Billboard's Hot 100 chart, the Beatles had a large number of ultra popular songs, including "Hey Jude," "Can't Buy Me Love," "Help!," and "Hard Day's Night."{{r|Marvel Comics Super Special Vol 1 4}}

| HistoryText             = The history of the Beatles on [[Earth-616]] mirrors that of their [[Wikipedia:Beatles|real world counterparts]] until about 1964. The intent of this page is to explore the events that are unique to the Earth-616 version of the Beatles. In some cases the Beatles have been depicted as being active during the [[Glossary:Modern Age|Modern Age]]. Barring any sort of explanation these should be considered [[Glossary:Topical Reference|topical references]] per the [[Glossary:Sliding Timescale|Sliding Timescale]] of [[Earth-616]].

==Skrulls==
[[File:Beatles (Skrulls) (Earth-616) from Wisdom Vol 1 6 002.jpg|left|thumb]]
The [[Beatles (Skrulls) (Earth-616)|Skrull Beatles]] were a group of [[Skrulls]] that took on the appearances of the original Beatles, with each taking the form of a Beatle. The faux-Beatles were intended to take the place of the real Beatles, and use their positions to launch a Skrull invasion. [[John Lennon (Skrull) (Earth-616)|John]], however, thought the Skrull Beatles could do more than an alien invasion, and convinced their bosses to give them free reign. Much like the real Beatles, the Skrull Beatles eventually found their interests leading in different directions, leading to the band's break-up. They were all later revealed to have been killed,{{r|Captain Britain and MI-13 #1}} save for John, who died later.{{r|Captain Britain and MI-13 #4}}

==Apocryphal Appearances==
Unless these appearances can be attributed to the Skrull Beatles, the following "appearances" of the Beatles should be considered topical references. 

During the early days of the [[Fantastic Four (Earth-616)|Fantastic Four]], the [[Benjamin Grimm (Earth-616)|Thing]] and [[Jonathan Storm (Earth-616)|Human Torch]] took their girlfriends [[Alicia Masters (Earth-616)|Alicia Masters]] and [[Doris Evans (Earth-616)|Doris Evans]] out to see a live musical performance. When the box office was robbed, the pair stopped the crooks responsible. During this ordeal, they crossed paths with the musicians in question. These musicians have been depicted as the Beatles as they appeared circa 1965.{{r|Strange Tales Vol 1 130}} 

The wedding [[Reed Richards (Earth-616)|Mister Fantastic]] and the [[Susan Storm (Earth-616)|Invisible Girl]] attracted a massive audience, including members of the superhero community and celebrities.{{r|Fantastic Four Annual #3}} In at least one account, musicians resembling the Beatles were depicted as being in attendance.{{r|Marvels Vol 1 2}}

==References==
The work of the Beatles (or their Skrull impersonators) have had a cultural impact on many of the costumed heroes of the Earth-616 universe. There are many instances where various characters sing music by, or made reference to, the Beatles.

The Beatles wig that Thing wore was given to him by the [[Yancy Street Gang (Earth-616)|Yancy Street Gang]].{{r|Fantastic Four #34}}

[[Henry McCoy (Earth-616)|Beast]] of the X-Men while singing under the [[Manipulator (Robot) (Earth-616)|Manipulator]]'s control, replaces 'Father McKenzie' with 'Professor Xavier' in Beatles' classic ''Eleanor Rigby''.{{r|Avengers Vol 1 178}}

While testing [[Dominic Destine (Earth-616)|Dominic Destine]] to determine if they are from the same reality, [[Katherine Pryde (Earth-616)|Kitty Pryde]] asked him about The Beatles, Madonna, John Wayne and [[Winston Churchill]].{{r|ClanDestine Vol 2 3}}

[[James Braddock, Jr. (Earth-1610)|Jim Braddock]] hummed a song from the Beatles as he messed with the [[X-Men (Earth-616)|X-Men]], deciding ''Helter Skelter'' to be too obvious, and passing on ''Magical Mystery Tour''.{{r|Uncanny X-Men Vol 1 472}}

[[Karolina Dean (Earth-616)|Karolina Dean]] is a fan of the Beatles{{r|Runaways #9}} especially the song [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucy_in_the_Sky_with_Diamonds "Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds"]. Her chosen codename was '''[[Lucy in the Sky]]''',{{r|Runaways #6}} and [[Xavin (Earth-616)|Xavin]] chose "Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds" as their wedding song for Karolina.{{r|Runaways Vol 2 14}}

| Notes                   = * The character of [[Rocket Raccoon]] is a lampoon of the near-eponymous character featured in the song ''Rocky Raccoon'' from the Beatles' 1968 "White Album." The story from the song, which involves Rocky's attempt to save his girlfriend from a villain, reflects events chronicled in {{cl|Incredible Hulk Vol 1 271}}. The title to this issue, "Now Somewhere In the Black Holes of Sirius Major There Lived a Young Boy Name of Rocket Raccoon!" is a play on the opening lyric of the song, "Now somewhere in the black mountain hills of Dakota, There lived a young boy named Rocky Raccoon." Another Beatles reference is Rocket's sidekick Wal Rus who happens to be a talking Walrus. ''Magical Mystery Tour'' had the song ''I Am the Walrus'' and Paul McCartney wearing a mask of the pinniped, something referenced in another track of the White Album, ''Glass Onion'' ("here's a clue to you all\the Walrus was Paul").{{r|Incredible Hulk Vol 1 271}}
* The title of {{cl|Daredevil Vol 1 101}}; "Vengeance in the Sky with Diamonds!" is imitative of the iconic Beatles song [[Wikipedia:Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds|''Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds'']].
* The story title, "Beetlemania!" of the issue {{cl|Spider-Man: Web of Doom Vol 1 3}}, is a play on the fervor that gripped America when The Beatles arrived in the early 1960s, a near-hysteria known as "Beatlemania."
* The issue {{cl|Not Brand Echh Vol 1 12}} parodies popular Beatles songs, with lyrics rearranged to be all about the [[Howling Commandos]].
* The tagline to {{cl|Iron Man Vol 1 119}} is "Back in the U.S.S.R.!" This is a reference to the 1968 song by The Beatles which opens the White Album.
* The main characters of the first story in {{cl|Dark X-Men Vol 1 1}} are given short descriptions, the last line of each is also the name of a Beatles song.
* The iconic image of The Beatles crossing [[Abbey Road]] in parodied in the {{cl|X-Men Vol 4 1}} Deadpool-themed variant cover.
